article.title: Branched covers of quasipositive links and L-spaces

choices: A.  A strongly quasipositive knot.
B.  The orientation of strands in a pretzel knot with  ε<sub>i</sub> = 1 and ε<sub>i+1</sub> = -1.
C. A band move that transforms a pretzel knot into a torus knot.
D. A Seifert surface for a pretzel link.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is being depicted in Figure 2?
choices: A. Minimal diagrams of 3-strand pretzel links.
B. Possible orientations for a 3-strand pretzel link L = P(p, q, r) with p even.
C. Steps in calculating the signature of a 3-strand pretzel link.
D. Examples of strongly quasipositive 3-strand pretzel links.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the plumbing diagrams in Figure 3 represent?
choices: A. Different methods for calculating the signature of an odd type Montesinos knot.
B. Two equivalent plumbing diagrams for K(−d<sub>1</sub>/(2d<sub>1</sub>+1), ..., −d<sub>r</sub>/(2d<sub>r</sub>+1) | 1).
C. The construction of a Seifert surface for an odd type Montesinos knot.
D. The proof that odd type Montesinos knots are strongly quasipositive.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the diagrams in Figure 4 illustrate?
choices: A. Different stages in the plumbing calculus for an even type Montesinos knot.
B. Different Seifert surfaces for an even type Montesinos knot.
C. The proof that even type Montesinos knots are fibred.
D. Examples of even type Montesinos knots with different numbers of branches.
A. The 2-bridge knot K(k, 2).
B. The tangle T(k) with k vertical negative half-twists.
C. A strongly quasipositive knot with k crossings.
D. A pretzel knot with k strands.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the tangle shown in Figure 6?
choices: A. It represents the case when k<sub>i</sub> = ∞ in the link L(k<sub>1</sub>, k<sub>2</sub>, k<sub>3</sub>).
B. It is used to construct the 2-bridge knot K(k, 2).
C. It is an example of a non-quasipositive tangle.
D. It is a building block for constructing strongly quasipositive knots.
A. The local difference between the links L, L<sub>0</sub>, and L<sub>∞</sub>.
B. The construction of an additive triple.
C. The relationship between alternating and strongly quasipositive links.
D. The effect of changing a crossing in a link diagram.
A. The definition of the Tristram-Levine signature function.
B. The calculation of the genus of a locally flat surface.
C. The Murasugi-Tristram inequality for a locally flat surface F with oriented boundary L.
D. The calculation of the first Betti number of a branched cyclic cover.
